content: Orchestration in agent systems consists of five main layers: Intake, Coordination, Execution, Synthesis, and Validation. Most current systems only implement two or three of these layers.
The Intake layer (L1) of an orchestration spine is the 'front door' where all incoming tasks, links, or messages are captured, preventing loss of information before work begins.
The Coordination layer (L2) handles task routing and planning, acting as a 'traffic controller' to decide which agent performs which task.
The Execution layer (L3) is where agents perform their work, taking action, delegating sub-tasks, and spawning sub-agents as needed.
The Synthesis layer (L4) aggregates results from agents, resolves conflicts, and creates a clean brief, preventing agent work from failing to translate into decisions.
The Validation layer (L5) performs quality checks on output, ensuring system health and preventing small errors from accumulating into garbage results.

The 'intelligence mesh' is a shared brain that allows every agent across all orchestration layers to access what other agents have learned, enabling seamless communication and collaboration without human intervention.
